title: Constraint Optimized Multichannel Mixer-limiter Design
author: Yuancheng Luo (Amazon.com), Dmitriy Yamkovoy (Amazon.com), Guillermo Garcia (Amazon.com), ..., Mikeluo (Amazon.com)
relevance_why: This work addresses multichannel audio processing, which resonates with Dr. Liu's interests in audio enhancement and restoration, potentially providing insights on mixer-limiter designs applicable to music and speech.
background: Designing a multichannel audio mixer and limiter to manage dynamic range and prevent distortion while reproducing audio over speaker arrays.
contribution: This paper introduces a quadratic programming formulation for coupled mixer-limiter design to optimize distortion while adhering to dynamic range constraints, achieving reduced audio distortion.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods often separated mixing and limiting stages, leading to potential distortion and inefficiencies in resource-constrained environments.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work couples the mixer and limiter stages, using a linear-constrained quadratic programming approach to enhance real-time performance and minimize distortion.

key_innovation: The proposed method effectively integrates mixer and limiter functionalities, applying time-varying gain adjustments linked to audio constraints for better audio fidelity in multichannel settings.
real_world_impact: The practical applications of this design could improve audio experiences in consumer electronics, enhancing sound quality in everyday devices such as smart speakers and soundbars.
limitations: The paper does not address hardware limitations or real-world implementational complexities that could affect the design's efficiency.

new_terms.quadratic programming: **Quadratic programming** is an optimization technique where the objective function is quadratic and constraints are linear, commonly used for optimizing a specific outcome under defined limits.
new_terms.constant overlap-add: **Constant overlap-add** is a method for efficiently processing overlapping segments of a digital signal to reduce artifacts during audio mixing or transformation.
